complexityAnalysis.taskTitle: Setup Electron and Next.js Project Structure
complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Break down the setup of Electron and Next.js project structure into subtasks such as initializing Next.js, installing Electron, integrating electron-next, configuring main and renderer processes, setting up build scripts, and verifying the development launch.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: This task involves multiple setup steps across two frameworks, including configuration and integration, but follows established guides and conventions, making it moderately complex.[1][3][5]

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Decompose the project management module into subtasks: set up navigation, implement TabContext, build ProjectList, ProjectTab, and ProjectDetails components, integrate SWR for data fetching, connect CRUD operations to Supabase, and write unit/integration tests.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: This module requires advanced UI/UX, state management, data fetching, and integration with backend services, making it a complex and central feature.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Break down PRD upload and processing into subtasks: implement file upload UI, handle file reading, connect to Task Master API, parse responses, store tasks in Supabase, integrate GPT-4 for refinement, and test the workflow.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: This task involves file handling, API integration, data parsing, and optional AI processing, each with their own edge cases and error handling.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Expand the task management interface into subtasks: implement Kanban board, build TaskBoard, TaskColumn, and TaskCard components, create TaskDetailPanel, integrate drag-and-drop, connect to Supabase for real-time updates, and test all features.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: Building a real-time, interactive Kanban board with drag-and-drop and live updates is UI-intensive and requires careful state and data management.

complexityAnalysis.description: Breaks down tasks into a hierarchy of goals, sub-goals, operations, and plans, providing a structured view of task components and their relationships.
complexityAnalysis.use_case: Useful for understanding complex tasks by decomposing them into manageable parts, facilitating efficient planning and scheduling.

complexityAnalysis.description: Focuses on the mental processes involved in task performance, such as decision-making, problem-solving, and memory recall, to understand cognitive demands.
complexityAnalysis.use_case: Beneficial for tasks requiring critical thinking or complex decision-making, aiding in designing systems that support user cognition.

complexityAnalysis.description: Creates a deliverable-oriented decomposition of a project into smaller components, organizing work into manageable sections.
complexityAnalysis.use_case: Effective for project management by breaking down complex projects into structured tasks, enhancing clarity and control.

complexityAnalysis.method: Goals, Operators, Methods, and Selection Rules (GOMS) Model
complexityAnalysis.description: Analyzes tasks by identifying goals, the operators used to achieve them, methods for combining operators, and rules for selecting among methods.
complexityAnalysis.use_case: Useful for evaluating user interface design and human-computer interaction by modeling user behavior.

complexityAnalysis.description: Measures the number of linearly independent paths through a program's source code, indicating its complexity.
complexityAnalysis.use_case: Applied in software development to assess code complexity, aiding in testing and maintenance efforts.

complexityAnalysis.description: Estimates the computational complexity of an algorithm by assuming a probabilistic distribution of all possible inputs.
complexityAnalysis.use_case: Used to design efficient algorithms or derive complexity of known algorithms under average-case scenarios.

complexityAnalysis.description: Decomposes complex problems recursively into smaller sub-problems, solving each independently before combining solutions.
complexityAnalysis.use_case: Commonly used in algorithms for searching and sorting, enhancing efficiency by breaking down tasks.

complexityAnalysis.description: Solves complex problems by breaking them down into simpler subproblems, storing the results to avoid redundant computations.
complexityAnalysis.use_case: Effective for optimization problems where subproblems overlap, improving computational efficiency.

complexityAnalysis.description: Solves problems recursively by trying to build a solution incrementally, removing solutions that fail to satisfy constraints.
complexityAnalysis.use_case: Utilized in scenarios like puzzle solving and combinatorial problems where all possibilities are explored.

complexityAnalysis.description: Reduces the use of nested loops by maintaining a subset of data in a 'window' and moving it through the dataset.
complexityAnalysis.use_case: Applied in scenarios requiring efficient data processing over a sequence, such as in string or array problems.
